. Hi there,
We just tried with the following patch in the last Kali version 1.1.0 and it's working like a charm:
(We only added recommendations from your last comments)
``` patch
diff --git a/faraday.py b/faraday.py
index 9f83ad2..8afa565 100755
--- a/faraday.py
+++ b/faraday.py
@@ -20,28 +20,16 @@ import subprocess
 import pip
from utils.logs import getLogger
-sys.path.insert(0, os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(file))) # Necessary?
+sys.path.insert(0, os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(file)) + '/external_libs/lib/python2.7/dist-packages')
 from config.configuration import getInstanceConfiguration
 from config.globals import *
 from utils.profilehooks import profile
-QTDIR='/usr/local/qt'
-PATH='%s/bin:%s'  %(QTDIR, os.environ['PATH'])
-MANPATH='%s/doc/man' % QTDIR
-LD_LIBRARY_PATH='%s/lib:%s' % (QTDIR, os.environ.get('LD_LIBRARY_PATH', ''))
-
-libs_exports =  {
-'QTDIR': QTDIR,
-'PATH': PATH,
-'MANPATH': MANPATH,
-'LD_LIBRARY_PATH': LD_LIBRARY_PATH
-}
-
-os.environ.update(libs_exports)
USER_HOME = os.path.expanduser(CONST_USER_HOME)
 FARADAY_BASE = os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(file))
+QTDIR=os.path.join(FARADAY_BASE, 'external_libs', 'qt')
FARADAY_USER_HOME = os.path.expanduser(CONST_FARADAY_HOME_PATH)
 FARADAY_PLUGINS_PATH = os.path.join(FARADAY_USER_HOME,
@@ -308,7 +296,6 @@ def startFaraday():
     print(Fore.RESET + Back.RESET + Style.RESET_ALL)
 exit_status = start()



restoreQtrc()
return exit_status


@@ -343,30 +330,15 @@ def setupQtrc():
     Existing qtrc files will be backed up and faraday qtrc will be set.
 """

-
-    if os.path.isfile(USER_QTRC):
-        shutil.copy2(USER_QTRC, USER_QTRCBAK)
-
-    if os.path.isfile(FARADAY_QTRCBAK):
-        shutil.copy(FARADAY_QTRCBAK, USER_QTRC)
-    else:
-        if not os.path.exists(USER_QT):
-            os.makedirs(USER_QT)
-        shutil.copy(FARADAY_QTRC, USER_QTRC)
-        shutil.copy(FARADAY_QTRC, FARADAY_QTRCBAK)
-
-def restoreQtrc():
-    """Restores user qtrc.
-
-    After exiting faraday the original qtrc is restored.
-
-    """
-
-    logger.info("Restoring user Qt configuration.")
-    shutil.copy2(USER_QTRC, FARADAY_QTRCBAK)
-    if os.path.isfile(USER_QTRCBAK):
-        shutil.copy(USER_QTRCBAK, USER_QTRC)
-
+    from ctypes import cdll
+    try:
+        import qt
+    except:
+        try:
+            cdll.LoadLibrary(os.path.join(QTDIR, 'lib', 'libqt.so'))
+            cdll.LoadLibrary(os.path.join(QTDIR, 'lib', 'libqui.so'))
+        except:
+            pass
def setupZSH():
     """Cheks and handles Faraday's integration with ZSH.
diff --git a/install.sh b/install.sh
index 97a73c1..5030d31 100755
--- a/install.sh
+++ b/install.sh
@@ -77,14 +77,8 @@ if [ "$down" -eq 1 ]; then
     if [ -e lib-$version.tgz ]; then
         if [ "echo ${!shav}" = "sha256sum lib-$version.tgz | awk -F\" \" \{'print $1'\}" ]; then
             echo "[+] SHA256 ok"
-            tar -xvzf lib-$version.tgz
-          
-            cp -R lib-$version/ /usr/local/
-            cp -R lib-$version/qt/lib/so* /usr/local/lib
-
-            cat deps/qtvars >> /etc/profile
-            . /etc/profile          
-            ldconfig
+            tar -xvzf lib-$version.tgz 
+            mv lib-$version/ external_libs
         else
             echo "[-] SHA256 file corrupt"
             exit
```

. Hi @lfatty,
Thanks for reaching out. What is happening is that you have not yet configured couchdb.
If you are using the QT GUI:
https://github.com/infobyte/faraday/wiki/Couchdb
If you are using the --gui=no-gui option
1) Edit the following file: ~/.faraday/config/user.xml
2) Search for the following tags (couch_uri) and set them, normally is like this
http://127.0.0.1:5984
3) Start couchdb: sudo service couchdb start
4) start faraday by running: ./faraday.py
4) Using a browser go to http://127.0.0.1:5984/reports/_design/reports/index.html (if you are using couch in a different IP, set it to the right address)
Let me know if this works,

. Thanks for the information.
From the screenshot I can guess you are using the cscan tool. 
In order to Faraday process this files you have to open Faraday using the QT version just ./faraday.py and select your workspace "cr-search"
You have to copy the report to your active workspace:
cp cscan/output/* /root/.faraday/report/cr-search/
I recommend you to read the following post:
http://blog.infobytesec.com/2015/09/faraday-continuous-scanning.html
Let me know if this help you.
. Could you explain a little more? What data are talking about? 
cscan it is tool to do continuous scanning but you have to copy the report inside Faraday.
. For now the only way to automatically copy the cscan output files is using a cron. You can configure cscan to output directly to $HOME/.faraday/report/cr-search/ but It is not a good option because some of the plugin (for example nikto) create the file before the scan finish so Faraday will end processing a unfinished scan report.

. Hi @rebbdohr
If you are using docker on macOS you have to bind the ports and use the docker-machine IP address to connecting to the docker container.
You have to run the following command:
$ docker run -it -p 5984:5984 -p 44:22 infobyte/faraday /root/run.sh
Then you have to get your default IP:
$ docker-machine ip default
                                                                                                                                                    192.168.99.100
And then you will get access the Web UI using that IP:
http://192.168.99.100:5984/_ui
If you like to enter in the SSH you have to use ssh root@192.168.99.100 -p 44
Let us know if that help to get fix your connection problem.
You can read more info on:
https://forums.docker.com/t/using-localhost-for-to-access-running-container/3148/3

. @caoimhinp, thanks for reporting. We are aware of this bug, sadly it won't be fixed until next release (ETA 1 month or two). 
Never the less I attach a patch for you to try.
`` patch
diff --git a/faraday b/faraday
index a174e1e..3233b4d 100755
--- a/faraday
+++ b/faraday
@@ -26,7 +26,16 @@ red_bg=tput setab 1rev_color=tput revbold=tput bold## Configuration
-faraday_base=pwd`
+
+# Absolute path to this script, e.g. /home/user/bin/foo.sh
+SCRIPT=$(readlink -f "$0")
+echo "DEBUG $SCRIPT"
+# Absolute path this script is in, thus /home/user/bin
+faraday_base=$(dirname "$SCRIPT")
+cd $faraday_base
+
+echo "DEBUG $faraday_base"
+
 faraday_user="$HOME/.faraday"
 #platforms
 arch=$(uname -m)
@@ -208,7 +217,7 @@ else
 fi
 if [ $faraday_os == Darwin ]; then
    echo [!] OSX support is limited
-   python main.py $@
+   python $faraday_base/main.py $@
 else
-   $faraday_pyver main.py $@
+   $faraday_pyver $faraday_base/main.py $@
 fi
```

diff --git a/install.sh b/install.sh
index 97a73c1..74856a4 100755
--- a/install.sh

@@ -79,8 +79,8 @@ if [ "$down" -eq 1 ]; then

cp -R lib-$version/* /usr/local/

echo "pwd/lib-$version/qt/lib" > /etc/ld.so.conf.d/faraday.conf

. Hi again!
createAndAddVulnToInterface is not a valid method in our XML RPC API, this is a list with all valid methods...
createAndAddApplication
createAndAddHost
createAndAddInterface
createAndAddNoteToHost
createAndAddNoteToNote
createAndAddNoteToService
createAndAddServiceToApplication
createAndAddServiceToInterface
createAndAddVulnToHost
createAndAddVulnToService
createAndAddVulnWebToService
You can create vulns associate to hosts or services, not to interface.
So, you need create a service with 'createAndAddServiceToInterface' and later 'createAndAddVulnToService',
or you can use 'createAndAddVulnToHost'
Regards!
. Our Rest API, is coded in apis/rest/*

```
!/usr/bin/python2.7
from persistence.server import server
import time
server.FARADAY_UP = False
Change this with your Faraday server url

server.create_workspace('workspacename', 'DESCRIPTION', date_today, date_today, 'CUSTOMER NAME')

. Hi @snoopythesecuritydog.
We encourage users installing dependencies from pacman/yaourt. There's a package for a pip installation in the extra category (extra/python2-pip). All the dependencies will be added to the AUR package as well. 
And respect the default path of python in arch, as another Arch user, I strongly recommend never modifying the symlinks. Faraday is launched using python2 from the environment (/usr/bin/env python2), so there's no need to do such a thing.
Thank you very much for your feedback. Feel free to comment on any of my suggestions.

. It's not really better, I would like your installer to not touch any system wide setting. The idea was to have a wrapper script that sets the LD_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable before starting faraday. Something like this:
```
!/bin/sh
cd $(basename 0)
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="pwd/lib-$version/qt/lib:pwd/lib-$version/"
export PYTHONPATH="pwd/lib-$version/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/"
export QTDIR=""pwd/lib-$version/qt"
export PATH="$QTDIR/bin:$PATH"
./faraday.py
```

versions are supported for each module that you require (pinning an exact
version is always too strict for distributions like us, we need to know
the minimal version only, and the maximal version only when the dependency
broke its API in some way in the latest version).

`. Hello,
The following steps are for Kali Linux 2017.2, if you are using another distro please let us know.
To configure faraday at boot you need to go the systemd way (Debian 8 started using systemd).
The following steps are to give you an idea on how to configure the deamon on boot, you will need to change the contents of the configuration files. I recommend to follow the documentation link  about systemd before doing any change.
First step is to create the following files:
touch /etc/systemd/system/name.service
chmod 664 /etc/systemd/system/name.service
Then you have save a config in name.server like this one:
```
[Unit]
Description=service_description
After=network.target
[Service]
ExecStart=path_to_executable
Type=forking
PIDFile=path_to_pidfile
[Install]
WantedBy=default.target
```
Last steps are:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl start name.service
Please remeber that kali has restrictions to start network applications on boot
Check the full documentation of systemd here

. Hi,
You already have the role faraday_postgresql in postgresql ans it seems that your server.ini is missing the credentials.
You can reset the password from postgresql of the role faraday_postgresql using the query:
ALTER ROLE faraday_postgresql WITH PASSWORD 'databasesecretpassword';
then you will need to configure the server.ini manually on the database section:
[database]
connection_string =postgresql+psycopg2://faraday_postgresql:databasesecretpassword@database_host/faraday
Remember to change database_host with the ip of the database (usually localhost).
Ther first time you execute python manage.py initdb it will create everything and configure automatically the server.ini. initdb failed since it found the database role faraday_postgresql.
Another option is to drop the role faraday_postgresql, but this could make you lose information and it is not the recommended way.
Just in case another github user comes to this ticket, never delete the .faraday directory. If you really need to delete .faraday directory make sure you make a backup. Initdb generates configurations on the database using random password and it will be only saved on server.ini (if you delete this file you will lose the database password)

except Exception as ex:

Or after hard-realoding (open web developer tools and then right-click on refresh and select "empty cache and hard reload")? Just to check - are there any other issues with your installation? Do you have users set up in your CouchDB? Sorry about all the questions :D . It seems that you're missing a couple of Views in CouchDB. Please run the GTK client passing it the --update arg just once and let me know if that fixes the issue. $ python2 faraday.py --update. Can you try cloning the repo/downloading in a different dir and running that version out of the box?. This is related to how the Kali package is done. @sbrun do you think the package could be modified and instead of removing the option, just removing the GH pull lines and maintaining the --update arg?. Thanks @sbrun! @tsluyter get back to us if you have other issues :). Thanks for reporting this! It looks like a mismatch between the data Burp shows and what it provides to our API. Let me run a couple of tests on this matter and get back to you.. Sorry for the delay on this, I took a look at all the data you sent and there seem to be several different issues here: - HTML tags appear in text fields in the resulting issues in Faraday I'm working on this - titles missing from the resulting issues (detail, background, remediation) Regarding detail and background, I added them to the vuln fields, this change will be available in the next version. Regarding "remediation" I think it doesn't make much sense to add it since the field is already named "Resolution", it would be redundant. - "
Resolution:" is added before the Issue Background in resulting issues I removed it, this change will also be in our next release. - references missing from resulting issues There is no method in the Extender API to get them. I already contacted Burp support regarding this issue. - path, query, param name and parameters are wrong in resulting issue What do you mean? Looking at the code I can see that these come directly from Burp: param = getParam(req) issuename += "("+issue.getUrl().getPath()[0,20]+")" path = issue.getUrl().to_s request = issue.getRequest().to_s method = req.getMethod().to_s - warning from line 235 I couldn't reproduce it, does it happen every time you send an issue to Faraday? . Hi @synackme! So I changed the plugin a little bit. You can get the new version here. Unzip it and add it to Burp Extensions making sure that it loads properly and that the current extension is unloaded. An update on the issues: - HTML tags appear in text fields in the resulting issues in Faraday Available for testing in the new plugin version. - titles missing from the resulting issues (detail, background, remediation) Available for testing in the new plugin version. - "
Resolution:" is added before the Issue Background in resulting issues Available for testing in the new plugin version. - references missing from resulting issues Burp support answered that they plan on adding a method for getting the references to their API in the future but that the work isn't scheduled yet. - path, query, param name and parameters are wrong in resulting issue param name is always empty and parameters is a string with all the parameters in the issue. I contacted Burp support to get assistance on how to get only vulnerable param per issue. - warning from line 235 I saw the attachments and understand you are getting the warning but I just couldn't reproduce it in two separate Burp installations. Please try the new version of this plugin and let me know if the warning is still there. Faraday Burp extension v1.3 . @synackme were you able to try the new version of the plugin? Let us know!. Did you get a chance to try the new version? Let us know!. @synackme this was fixed in both the Burp Report Plugin and the Burp Online Extender Plugin. Let us know if you have any questions or comments :D. Thanks for the suggestions. We'll add these to the list of things to add to the web ui and get back to you once they're published.. Hi @tsluyter we've introduced some changes in the Services and Hosts perspective that I think you'll find useful :) Feel free to let us know how you feel about these changes! d3v1l401:
Good, it's working, but it's not the "workspace" tag you have to edit but "couch_uri" which was set to null (couch_uri).
I had to edit the tag to 
couch_uri>http://[IP]:5984/couch_uri>
Seems like it's not automatically configured (even if couchdb was configured to bind to the public IP) and the tag is set to null as default.
I hope you can fix this soon.
Thanks for the help and nice project.

. Hello @fnzv! Thanks for contacting us. 
A couple of questions: are your trying to run Faraday in a computer with an X server? You need it to run the graphical interface, so if you're trying to run it via SSH or something similar, you should set it up with X forwarding. 
Also, are you trying to run this as root? Sometimes that causes problems with the X server too.
You can try running Faraday with ./faraday.py --gui=nogui. If that runs, there's a problem with X somewhere and we can work from that. 
Have a nice day!
. @fnzv Hello! Faraday needs an X Server to show the graphical interface. You can run Faraday without a GUI (./faraday.py --gui=nogui) and then connect to it with Faraday Terminal (./fardaday-terminal.zsh). If you use it like this, you won't need an X server. Docker is not needed, either. 
Run ./faraday.py --gui=nogui and pay attention to a couple of lines like this:
2016-06-27 16:22:36,567 - faraday - INFO - XMLRPC API server configured on ('SERVER',PORT)
2016-06-27 16:22:36,650 - faraday - INFO - REST API server configured on ('SERVER',PORT)
Then run ./faraday-terminal.zsh like this:
./faraday-terminal.zsh SERVER PORT
Run faraday.py --help for more information on how to start Faraday connected to specific couchdb database, specific workspace, and such.

. @kendyhikaru Hello! We're sorry you are having trouble with the new version and we thank you for informing us of this issue. You have two options:
1) Continue using QT! Be aware that this interface is deprecated and will very soon be totally discarded from the program, but at the moment you can still run it by specifying the --gui=qt flag, provided you have the QT dependencies installed.
2) Apply this patch! This should fix any problem arising from using Ubuntu 14.04, VTE 2.90 and/or GObject Instronspection 3.12. We would be very glad to hear your feedback on this if you want to try it! We believe you should, as said, QT is going away soon anyway. 
In any case, to apply the patch just store the file somewhere, move to the Faraday root folder and apply the patch. For example, if you saved the patch in your home folder, run patch -p1 < ~/vte_290_patch.txt

I'm sorry for the inconvenience, I hope this fixes it for you and, again, I'm eager to hear any feedback you have on this!
. Hello @Sir-Fancy! 
We're going to try to reproduce this and get back to you. Thanks for the report! 
. @Sir-Fancy This may be a problem with Couch DB versions. What version are you using? Thanks for the feedback! 
. @Sir-Fancy OK, we'll look into this problem with the databases. 
As for the ~/.faraday directory. Did you install Faraday with the repos? Did you get to start Faraday at least once? The folder is created on startup. We are aware of a bug where icons weren't correctly copied to ~/.faraday/images/icons and it will be fixed in the in the next version. Was this related to this? 
. Hey @Sir-Fancy! Good news. Our previous hypothesis was wrong, and apparently this is really easy to fix. Did you check the owner user and group when moving the bugbounty DB to /var/lib? 
To fix this, just change the owner user and owner group to couchdb:daemon, for example with sudo chown couchdb:daemon /var/lib/couchdb/facebook.couch, if you were using the facebook database. If your CouchDB user or group differs, adapt the command accordingly. 
We'll add this step to our documentation ASAP, as we've now realized it is missing. Thank you very much! And we'll look into the ~/.faraday folder thing too!
Cheers!
. Hey @blacksecdefault! We're sorry we encountered trouble. We know about this issue, and luckily it has a simple fix and it will be fixed in the next release. 
Just run: 
cp -r $FARADAY_DIR/data/images/icons/ ~/.faraday/images/icons/
Of course replace $FARADAY_DIR with your Faraday installation path. 
Let us know if this fixed it!
. @itsnotqwerty Hi! Unfortunately, the metasplot online plugin is not working at the moment, but will be fixed in the next release, coming up in just a few days! 
The message you get, though, is completely normal: when activated, the plugin starts and ends in a loop until you disable it or close Faraday. That's how it keep track of changes in the database. 
. Hello @stillinsecure! We're sorry you're having trouble. Could you provide us with the output of cat $FARADAY/config/globals.py? Thank you! 
. @stillinsecure Looks like something went wrong with the update mechanism. Are you able to install Faraday without Docker? We shall be looking into this problem a releasing an updated version of the docker image in the near future. 
. Hello @kerlingcode!
Try to access http://127.0.0.1:5985. Do you see the CouchDB database? If you don't, there's a problem there. Double check this part of the setup:
Edit CouchDB configuration file. To do that, run couchdb -c to identify it and then edit it to change CouchDB port and bind_address in section [httpd]. Set bind_address to the IP you want for CouchBD and port to 5985.
If you do see the CouchDB databases there, then we just need to tell the server which port to use. That is this part of the setup:
Next edit ~/.faraday/config/server.ini and change Faraday Server port to 5984 in section [faraday_server] and set a new port for CouchDB in section [couch-db] (by default the server will expect CouchDB to use 5985).
Good luck! 
. @kerlingcode No bother, don't worry. I think I know what's going wrong: Faraday is trying to connect to CouchDB directly, when it should connect to Faraday server. See how the error says it can't connect to 127.0.0.1:5984? That's true, it should be connecting to 127.0.0.1:5985. To be sure, please post the output of these two commands:
curl 127.0.0.1:5984/_api/info
and 
curl 127.0.0.1:5985/_api/info
You should get a {"Faraday Server":"Running"} with one of those. The one who responded that is the one where the server is running, and Faraday should be connecting to that one. 
Nevertheless, the Faraday client should be opening and telling you it can't connect to the server, like this:

Does that happen? If it doesn't, please run ./faraday.py --debug to see what's going wrong. As a workaround, you can just change the server IP in ~/.faraday/config/user.xml, in the 'couch_uri' field. Even though it says couch_uri, that should be Faraday server's URL. The name is just to assure backwards compatibility.
. @kerlingcode We glad you've found the reason and that you've reported this. We'll be adding a better dependency checker for ZSH now that you mention this. Thank you for your time and we hope you enjoy Faraday! 
. @Dargin Hello! We're sorry you're having trouble. 
Just to check: what URL are you trying to access? You should be trying to access something like SERVER_URL:SERVER_PORT/_ui. Is that correct? As of Faraday 2.0, you should always be connecting to the server, never to CouchDB directly. 
Also, and just to be sure there's nothing weird going on with the browser, you could try accessing that URL in incognito mode? So we rule out weird cookies, caché, and stuff. 
. @Dargin Do you have credentials set for couchdb database? If so, check they are correctly configured in ~/.faraday/config/server.xml. 
Also, if case have you restarted CouchDB, you need to restart the server too. 
You could also try posting the output of ~/.faraday/log/faraday-server.log and ~/.faraday/log/faraday.log after you try accessing the dashboard? Keep in mind these could contain sensitive information, so redact them as you see fit. The last ~20 lines after you try accessing the dashboard should be enough, if there's too much sensitive data to paste the whole thing :) 
. @Dargin Dargin, this is probably related to a known issue we have with the --start option in the server. This will be fixed in the next release. 
In the meanwhile, you should now close the server and start it again with ./faraday-server.py (without the --start flag).
Please do report back if this solved your problem! :)

Saludos!. Hello dongtaofei,
Your issue is probably caused by a problem with the nessus certificates.
This should fix it:
```
~/d/f/scripts ❯❯❯ git diff cscan/plugin/nessus.py                                                                                                                           master ✱
diff --git a/scripts/cscan/plugin/nessus.py b/scripts/cscan/plugin/nessus.py
index 657eded..63e4d43 100755
--- a/scripts/cscan/plugin/nessus.py
+++ b/scripts/cscan/plugin/nessus.py
@@ -38,14 +38,15 @@ def connect(method, resource, data=None):
 data = json.dumps(data)


requests.packages.urllib3.disable_warnings()
     if method == 'POST':
r = requests.post(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=verify)
r = requests.post(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=False)
     elif method == 'PUT':
r = requests.put(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=verify)
r = requests.put(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=False)
     elif method == 'DELETE':
r = requests.delete(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=verify)
r = requests.delete(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=False)
     else:
r = requests.get(build_url(resource), params=data, headers=headers, verify=verify)

r = requests.get(build_url(resource), params=data, headers=headers, verify=False)
# Exit if there is an error.
 if r.status_code != 200:
```


In the nessus.py file (cscan/plugin/nessus.py) adds this line to your code: 
requests.packages.urllib3.disable_warnings()
Let us know if you are still having this issue or if anything else comes up,

. Hey there!
First of all, let me start by explaining how the status of vulns works on Faraday.
The idea of vulns status is to mark their current state on your target. Therefore a vuln will be automatically opened when just imported into faraday, can be changed to Closed for example if the vuln has been fixed and if a scan imported into faraday shows that same vulnerability again Faraday instead of creating a new vuln will mark the existent one as Re-Open to better keep track of said vuln.
You can read more about it on this wiki: https://github.com/infobyte/faraday/wiki/Vulnerability-Life-Cycle
What you did to integrate Faraday with Jira sounds amazing! Thought you should know out of the box integration with JIRA is one of the features that come with commercial versions of Faraday! If you would like a demo just to let us know.
Your vision of how to track the history of a vulns sounds  very interesting too, and i will talk to the developer team about maybe including it on our roadmap.
For now as a workaround, have you considered maybe changing the vuln status when sending it yo JIRA?
In any case thank you for the feedback and let us know how it goes!. 1) Yes it is possible on the new version. Faraday V3 has a brand new REST API made almost from scratch. If you go into the web ui and open de develover tools right before clicking on edit you'll the request that's made. If you copy that request and change the json you can edit any vulns directly from the API.
2) Notes has been deprecated on Faraday V3. FYI: Notes has been deprecated but replaced with a new section called Comments.. Hey there,

Cheers.. Hi there. 
We realised that you are missing the header 'Content-Type: application/json'. Make sure that you used it in all the requests to the API.
Here is a full example of how to use the comments in the API using curl. 


First login to the API. Remember to use 'Content-Type: application/json'
NOTE: in the "email" field you have to put your username. And in "password" put your username's password.
curl -s 'http://127.0.0.1:5985/_api/login' \
        -H 'Origin: http://127.0.0.1:5985' -H 'Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br' \
        -H 'Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9' \
        -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
        -H 'Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01' \
        -H 'Referer: http://127.0.0.1:5985/' -H 'X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest' \
        -H 'Connection: keep-alive' \
        --data-binary '{"email":"faraday","password": "Password123"}' \
        --compressed -c cookie.txt > /dev/null


To create the comment, you have to use POST and instead of "title", use "text" and remember the 'Content-Type: application/json'. The response will be a json with a new comment id. The json must contain object_type and object_id which correspond to Faraday object. Currently we support to comment host, service, comment. 
NOTE: In the example we comment a host with id: 1073.
curl -X POST http://127.0.0.1:5985/_api/v2/ws/openvas/comment/ -d '{"text": "https://jira.xxxxxx.eu/browse/SEC-103", "object_type": "host", "object_id": 1073}' -b cookie.txt -H 'Content-Type: application/json'


Our front-end doesn't show comments yet, but you can consult the API like this: 
curl -X GET http://127.0.0.1:5985/_api/v2/ws/openvas/comment/2/ -b cookie.txt -H 'Content-Type: application/json'
We realised that you are using PUT method, that is for update the comment. And in this case we need to create it, so we use then POST.


Remember that our commercial version supports JIRA integration and we can send you a demo for free if you want to try it out.  . Hi there. 
Here is an example of a function that uploads a report to Faraday.
```python
def login_faraday():
    # File to upload
    files = {'file': open('/PATH/TO/FILE', 'rb')}
s = requests.Session()
# /login
headers = {
    'Origin': 'http://127.0.0.1:5985',
    'Accept-Encoding': 'gzip, deflate, br',
    'Accept-Language': 'en-US,en;q=0.9',
    'Content-Type': 'application/json',
    'Accept': 'application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01',
    'Referer': 'http://127.0.0.1:5985/',
    'X-Requested-With': 'XMLHttpRequest',
    'Connection': 'keep-alive',
}   
data = '{"email":"faraday","password": "changeme"}'
response = s.post('http://127.0.0.1:5985/_api/login', headers=headers, data=data)
cookies = s.cookies.get_dict()

# /session
response_session = requests.get('http://127.0.0.1:5985/_api/session', cookies=cookies)
cookies_session = response_session.cookies.get_dict()
csrf_token = {'csrf_token': response_session.json()['csrf_token']}

# Uploading report
upload = requests.post('http://127.0.0.1:5985/_api/v2/ws/api/upload_report', data=csrf_token, cookies=cookies_session, files=files)

```
In order to be able to upload a report, you need the CSRF token and session's cookies. Remember that the requests parameters only take key/value pairs. That's why files is a dict.
If you want to upload a report by using cURL, here is an example:
curl  'http://127.0.0.1:5985/_api/v2/ws/api/upload_report' \
       -H 'Content-Type: multipart/form-data' \
       --cookie "session=.eJw90M2KwjAQB_BXWXL2YGu9CB6UlGJhpgSCZeZS2FpNJ2YXqkI24rtv18O-wO__8VTdeRpuTm3u02NYqG48qc1TfXyqjWK9SyyUYVsWmMrUWDei9Etsj4FaDKydw-Qj5KZo9CWSNUu2uzXktQM5XSnxyJVZgTaRrYkk-xEt5ZQfVmT3DmcfKvrhcBQUKMgeIoQysb0knjMh-QIEliyQQzJZ0-IV_kx7DWDZY1WPmNCD9Fv1Wqj-Np27-7cfvv4noNTSVCZjXSaYK2KgiLqMTTtX1H7daMpmPnLFgtpHSk7YbN_c4zZM7ztUoV6_3rRiDA.DkoypQ.q7eGzh1oof8dKnbF4q6xD_n1d6o" \
       --form "file=@PATH/TO/FILE" \
       --form "csrf_token=IjYyYzhkNWQxMzA4MTZmMTQxMTliYTA5OTg2NWYzMWRmYzQ5MWM4Y2Ui.Dko4Zw.sZ-LLdGoxaNFUaySFFQMvyLecxc" --compressed

I found the problem, the problem is the couchdb local.ini file ;require_valid_user = true
 if you uncomment this line it does not work. What this line does is:
require_valid_user¶
When this option is set to true, no requests are allowed from anonymous users. Everyone must be authenticated.
Which is required for a secure server in my opinion. It looks like a bug on the web ui code.

Hi faraday, are you guys releasing the new version soon with the extended api?
. Thanks for the solution! That solved my issue! And really really looking forward to that api! Thanks again for the good work you guys do! 
. Well done on the new update! did you guys add the new extended api or add and manage workspaces from the command line?
. Thanks! What i am really trying to accomplish is have an auto parser similar to some of the xml parsers that are built into faraday also. (ie. nmap, nikto etc). How can I go about start developing those?
. Thanks! I think i am starting to understand why I cant make this work using the resources available. I dont actually have a tool that i can convert into a plugin... What I have is a binary application testing VM, which once completed, generates various reports, one being XML. i want to be able to automatically import that XML report into faraday by renaming the file report_faraday_Myapplication.xml (like nmap, nikto, arachni, etc) for further processing. The reason why the existing templates doesnt work for me is because the xml data structure is different. Would faraday be able to develop the custom auto import plugin for us? We are in a POC for the paid version right now, and it helps us take one more step to evaluate on how we can truly utilize faraday. 
We can continue this conversation away from github and via email or phone if you want. 
Thanks! 
. Thanks. I think I may have misread about the XML format. But can you clarify how I can download the CSV report? I looked through everything, but dont see a download link. Perhaps you can share a screenshot that helps clarify?
. Got it! Thanks for the help!

No other users set up in Faraday, just myself. And don't be sorry, you're helping me :) . I'm starting to think that the Faraday version included with Kali is outdated, because the "--update" option isn't even available :)
root@kali:~# python /usr/share/python-faraday/faraday.py --help
usage: faraday.py [-h] [-n HOST] [-px PORT_XMLRPC] [-pr PORT_REST] [-d]
                  [--profile] [--profile-output PROFILE_OUTPUT]
                  [--profile-depth PROFILE_DEPTH] [--disable-excepthook]
                  [--dev-mode] [--ignore-deps] [--cert CERT_PATH] [--gui GUI]
                  [--cli] [-w WORKSPACE] [-r FILENAME]
However, according to APT I'm running the latest available package:
root@kali:~# apt-get upgrade python-faraday
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree       
Reading state information... Done
python-faraday is already the newest version (2.2.0-0kali1).. Alright, yes that has fixed it.

Stop the pre-installed Faraday client and server
Backup /var/lib/couchdb
git clone https://github.com/infobyte/faraday
cd faraday
./faraday-server.py &
./faraday.py --update

The --update option is known in this version and now the host detail screen does show the services. Layout isn't very pretty, but the original issue is gone. 
So, what's the problem? Was the pre-installed version with Kali Rolling both outdated and buggy?. Awesome! When can I expect that in the Kali repo's? :) 
Many thanks for your swift actions!. Absolutely wonderful! I appreciate it and I'll keep you posted.. Just wanted to confirm: the upgraded package is available through Kali's repository and it does work as discussed. The --update feature is onboard and everything works as expected. 
Thank you very much for your very fast help! I really appreciate it. . I've run into this issue in the past, where Faraday would become unstable upon pausing/resuming the VM that it runs on. Or after sleeping the laptop that the VM runs on. In that case, the workaround is to kill all Faraday processes, restart couchdb and restart the server + IDE. . Awesome. Thanks for the update!. That's awesome, thank you! I'd love this functionality to also make it into the GUI, but for now this'll do..
synackme:
More screenshots below: I took a closer look myself, and I found some things you might find useful: Errors in Burp's UI show that the problem is on line 235 of the faraday-burp.rb file. * Line 235: @stdout.println("New scan issue host: " +host +",name:"+ issuename +",IP:" + ip) I found out why the string "Resolution:" shows up in the Issue, its on Line 229 * desc+="
Resolution:" + issue.getIssueBackground().to_s The source speaks for itself. ```ruby if ctx == 5 or ctx == 6 or ctx == 2 issuename="Analyzing: " severity="Information" desc="This request was manually sent using burp" else desc=issue.getIssueDetail().to_s desc+="Resolution:" + issue.getIssueBackground().to_s severity=issue.getSeverity().to_s issuename=issue.getIssueName().to_s resolution=issue.getRemediationBackground().to_s end @stdout.println("New scan issue host: " +host +",name:"+ issuename +",IP:" + ip) begin rt = @server.call("devlog", "[BURP] New issue generation") h_id = @server.call("createAndAddHost",ip, "unknown") i_id = @server.call("createAndAddInterface",h_id, ip,"00:00:00:00:00:00", ip, "0.0.0.0", "0.0.0.0",[], ``` I've circled where the random "Resolution:" gets stuck in the issue description. Screenshot of errors on the faraday-server.pyc when sending the issue: Still need to dig deeper to find out why raw HTML is getting stored instead of text in addition to the lack query, path, etc. The "warning from line 235" is coming from Burp Extender's "Show in UI" text box. You can see it in the last image I uploaded, I put a red box around it. It is referring to line 235 in the faraday-burp.rb file (which is the faraday plugin). I am sorry, I have been out on leave for a while. It looks like you rolled out the fix in 2.3.0, although I haven't tested it. I will test it this morning and report back. Thanks.

     def __get_service_and_url_from_output(self, output):
        """ Return the service (http or https) and the base URL (URL without
        protocol) from a given string. In case more than one URL is found,
        return the service and base_url of the first one, ignore others.
        """
        search_url = re.search(r"URL: ((http[s]?)\:\/\/([\w.]+)[.\S]+)", output)
        service, base_url = search_url.group(2), search_url.group(3)

nmaxcom:
Same issue here. Upgrading and urllib3 didn't help. But this did:

First remove the package from the package manager:
apt-get remove python-pip
And then install the latest version by side: 
easy_install pip. I'm using Debian in a gcloud server. I can't even get in from the google dashboard. The server is up and running but denies my key It's really weird.

I saw it correctly upgrade to experimental I run ./faraday-server.py, server started fine and that's when tmux stopped responding to some key-bindings. I'm not a *nix expert at all so I don't know what could've happened. I've asked also somewhere, but could you think of some explanation whatsoever?

sebikul:
Could you please try to execute the following command:
$ sudo apt-get install --reinstall python-gi

And try running Faraday again. If there is any error running the command above, or running Faraday, please paste it here or upload it to pastebin again.
. Okey, let's see what modules the Python2 interpreter has available. Please execute this command and upload the output to pastebin:
$ python2 -c "help('modules')" . Could you please paste the output of the following command:

 echo $PATH. The problem is that when you are executing Faraday, your system is using your locally compiled Python interpreter, not the one installed from the repositories along with the dependencies we need. You can see that `/usr/local/bin` has a higher priority than `/usr/bin` in the `$PATH` variable.

The only fix that I can think of is to try to execute Faraday like this (this is, if you followed the installation steps correctly):
$ /usr/bin/python2 faraday.py

Otherwise, I would recommend you not to manually install software outside the package manager of your distribution, as errors like this can happen.. Glad that worked! Remember that executing python2 plainly on a console will launch the interpreter you compiled.

Your issue is probably caused by a problem with the nessus certificates.
This should fix it:
~/d/f/scripts ❯❯❯ git diff cscan/plugin/nessus.py                                                                                                                           master ✱
diff --git a/scripts/cscan/plugin/nessus.py b/scripts/cscan/plugin/nessus.py
index 657eded..63e4d43 100755
--- a/scripts/cscan/plugin/nessus.py
+++ b/scripts/cscan/plugin/nessus.py
@@ -38,14 +38,15 @@ def connect(method, resource, data=None):
 data = json.dumps(data)



requests.packages.urllib3.disable_warnings()
if method == 'POST':


r = requests.post(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=verify)


r = requests.post(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=False)
elif method == 'PUT':


r = requests.put(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=verify)


r = requests.put(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=False)
elif method == 'DELETE':


r = requests.delete(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=verify)


r = requests.delete(build_url(resource), data=data, headers=headers, verify=False)
else:


r = requests.get(build_url(resource), params=data, headers=headers, verify=verify)


r = requests.get(build_url(resource), params=data, headers=headers, verify=False)
# Exit if there is an error.
if r.status_code != 200:


In the nessus.py file (cscan/plugin/nessus.py) adds this line to your code:
requests.packages.urllib3.disable_warnings()
Let us know if you are still having this issue or if anything else comes up,
Cheers!

. I resolved it myself! :). Resolving Last Workspace Error:
    - Remove current faraday configuration files using rm ~/.faraday/config/
    - Configure new service.ini, config.xml and user.xml files
    - Do the right configurations on CouchDB and Faraday-server server.ini 
    - Login to CouchDB through its web interface with admin credentials and stay logged in
          (http://X.X.X.X:5984/_utils/)
    - Then go to http://X.X.X.X:5985/_ui and then create a new workspace e.g. "test"
    -  Go to the ~/.faraday/config/user.xml and change the "last workspace" same as the one you already created on the previous step through web UI 
     test
    - Restart Faraday server and CouchDB service and then run the faraday client 
The issue should be resolved now!. I assume, I solved the issue by adding the "plugin name" into the xml file name ( as it has been mentioned in the Wiki plugin section). I tried something like the following and it worked!
./faraday.py --cli --workspace aug-faraday-nexpose --report Aug_faraday_Nexpose.xml
And I got the following result:
2018-08-16 13:38:29,350 - faraday - INFO [api.py:110 -      _setUpAPIServer() ]  XMLRPC API server configured on ('10.224.60.75', 9876)

So, I would say it seems to be a bug as it cannot recognize most of the plugins including but not limited to OpenVAS, Nexpose, and Nmap with v3 automatically when you trying to upload an xml file ( at least in my case which Faraday is installed in a RedHat 7 box). With Faraday v2.7 in the same box, I never had an issue like this!. Hi,
As I mentioned above through CLI using the following command:
./faraday.py --cli --workspace aug-vuln --report Aug_vulnreport.xml
and it did not work until I manually included the plugin name ( in this case: Nexpose) keyword within the xml file name as below:
./faraday.py --cli --workspace aug-faraday-nexpose --report Aug_faraday_Nexpose.xml
. Hi WinnaZ,
I have been working with Faraday for the last two years and I've never faced with the issue like this. Previous versions of Faraday (even through CLI) always detected plugins automatically (at least for the below-mentioned plugins in my case), without any needs to put the plugin name in the XML file name! It used to work perfectly with many plugins such as Nexpose, Nessus, Acunetix, OpenVAS, Nmap, OWASP ZAP etc.
Thanks!. Hi Winnaz,
Another important issue that I just realized is that when you importing report (let's say generated from Nexpose which used to work fine within version 2.7), Faraday cannot parse the XML report file correctly ( for any reason). For example, the total number of the vulnerabilities (vuln) is much smaller than the actual report or there is no "critical" vulnerability at all. I could not even find some of the "hosts" or "vulnerabilities" which were in the actual XML/CSV report generated from the Nexpose itself. 
I also tried to upload the report from Web UI, but got the same result. Long story short, the number of the "total Vulns" and "Critical and High Severity" are away smaller than the actual report. Those items that I just mentioned were pretty much the same as the actual report in previous versions of the Faraday. I can provide more details to prove my claim but I assume that there are some serious bugs at least for the specific plugins in version 3 when it comes to uploading a report.
Cheers,
Hank. Hi @llazzaro ,
Sorry for some security reasons and my company policies, I can not provide the XML file for now. but I'm providing you with the following screenshots from the actual Nexpose scan results and results that are shown in the Faraday. I also compared the Nexpose scan XML file imported into the Faraday v3 and the same file imported in Faraday v2.7!
I selected a random host "X.X.129.213" and I poked around in the actual Nexpose scan result. I found more than one vulnerability for that specific host and even one of them was a "high" severity.

In the Faraday v3 (after importing the Nexpose XML file into it), that host has only one "low" vulnerability (obviously with a different CVE number which was correct) and nothing else! there is no sign of the above mentioned "high" vuln with its related CVE!! 



Although that "low" vuln had been correctly shown in the Faraday v3, there were no "high" and "critical" vulnerabilities related to that host.
It was just an example which shows that in Faraday v3 (at least for the Nexpose plugin) there might be something wrong.
It gets even worse when you compare the number of total vulnerabilities for the same XML file in Faraday v3 and Faraday v2.7:
Total number of host = is the same in both versions  > 297
Total number of services = is the same in both versions > 1076
Total number of vuln in Faraday v3 = 209
Total number of vuln in Faraday v2.7 ( was originally from CouchDB database) = 11124
!! the number of total vulns in v2.7 is bigger by far!

I don't think the Nexpsoe version cause the issue as the same file was imported in both Faraday v3 and v2.7! I also created a new file for the same scan within the latest Nexpose (6.5.31), I uploaded it into Faraday v3, no improvement!
